title: Ex-rookie blames Eagles culture for decline
text:
Ben Sharp blames ’volcanic’ West Coast drugs culture for decline February 9, 2017 2:30pm by Tyson Otto Source: news.com.au FORMER West Coast Eagles player Ben Russell Sharp has blamed his former club’s aggressive culture of drug use for the complete ruination of his career and personal life. 
The day after the 30-year-old pleaded guilty to charges of armed robbery and drug trafficking in the Victorian County Court, AFL legend Garry Lyon described the infamous West Coast Eagles drugs culture as “volatile and volcanic”. 
Sharp, a former friend of troubled AFL great Ben Cousins, will be sentenced on April 4 after pleading guilty with his brother and another man to using a sawn-off shotgun and a handgun to rob a guarded van which was carrying $287,000 collected from three McDonald’s restaurants in Melbourne’s western suburbs. 
The former Werribee best and fairest winner’s barrister Peter Kilduff claimed Sharp’s personal problems could all be traced back to the drug abuse issues that he first experienced after joining the Eagles officially as a 19-year-old through the 2007 rookie draft. 
Kilduff told the court Sharp was approached by a senior Eagles player during his first pre-season and told “you’re either in or you’re out” in regards to the culture of drug use. 
“They all trained together and they all partied together,” he said. Ben Sharp playing for Werribee in the VFL. Source: News Limited 
“This is an 18-year-old man ready and willing to play top class football, and he blows it all.” 
The court was told Sharp began using cocaine while playing for the Eagles and that he also experimented with ice. 
In a report submitted to the court, Sharp said he used cocaine as a way to fit-in with his new teammates. 
“I had to use cocaine,” he said. 
“I thought it was a way to get in with the boys, so I used coke.” 
Kilduff said Sharp was dragged into the scene by influential senior West Coast players. 
The Herald Sun reported in 2015 that Sharp was smoking $200 worth of ice per day when he committed the robbery in December, 2014. 
After his arrest, Sharp told police he had been using the drug on and off for 10 years. 
When asked if he was using more ice at the time of the robbery, Sharp told them his habit had always been large. 
“Probably about the same really,’’ he told police. 
Sharp featured in Cousins’ tell-all book Ben Cousins: My Life Story in 2010. 
In it, Cousins said he used his last phone call to ring Sharp after he’d been arrested outside Crown while off his face. Ben Cousins continues to struggle with his reported ice addiction. Source: AAP 
Cousins wrote that Sharp told police to “f*** off’’, which earned Cousins some additional time in the cells. 
Melbourne Demons legend Garry Lyon said it is clear that there is more to the story than is publicly known about the West Coast Eagles’ drugs problems. 
Brownlow Medallist Ben Cousins is due back in court in June over an outstanding drug charge while club legend Chris Mainwaring died in 2007 following a cocaine binge. 
“We all know the volatile, volcanic behaviours that were going on through that period,” Lyon told SEN’s Garry, Tim and Hamish . 
“It’s an untold story still there.” 
It came as AFL Players’ Association boss Paul Marsh confirmed more and more players and former players are seeking support from association over issues surrounding drug use. 
“We have a number of things we can do for players,” Marsh told SEN. 
“We have a national psych network. So any player who is a member of the PA can ring in and access our services, confidentially and free. More and more players are doing that. The guys who are doing it very tough from a hardship perspective, we have a fund set up to help players when they need help in that space.
